Radio-Diffusive Particulate Clouds Coupled with MASERs for Prevention of Triangulation of Covert Ground-Ground and Ground-Space Communications

Even given the advent of true entanglement-based communication, it may not always be practical or desirable to field the experimental communicators in contested environments. The capture of such an advanced technology by an adversary would risk the compromise of the manufacturing process that makes possible the communicators. In any case, early models only use entanglement for key distribution purposes and lack sufficient bandwidth for transmission of whole messages, at least for now.

This means that a methodology is required for disguising the location of radio transmission sources for critical communications that need to be transmitted from contested areas where adversary radio triangulation devices are ubiquitous (cell towers fulfill this function of signals intercept and triangulation for most intents and purposes.)

Just as microscopic listening devices may be disseminated in airborne clouds as delinated in a publication a number of months ago, it stands to reason that such plumes could be used to carry particulates that serve the function of reflecting focused microwave energy in all directions so that a transmission may be beamed to a plume from a great distance using focused energy and would seem to be coming from the center of the plume from the perspective of adversary eavesdropping equipment.

For an operative behind enemy lines, this system could be employed by opening a window and spraying an aerosol disguised as hairspray out the window and waiting for a period of time for the invisible plume to be carried in a known direction, sufficiently distant to hide the signal source.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
The operative would then; from a position of concealment; emit the MASER beam with encoded information toward the plume, which would likely be composed of lightweight flakes with metallic properties with a three-dimensional configuration similar to a store-bought stick-on bow like what would be affixed atop a gift box. This shape would ensure omnidirectional reflection of the signal.

At that point, the signal could be picked up by other operatives in a specific area on the ground, or by satellite. By the same token, tasking could be sent to operatives on the ground by sending a radio signal toward a plume from space which would then diffuse outward from a point at the surface, preventing triangulation of the satellite itself.

As long as operatives on the ground take care not to point their MASER devices toward cell towers, their signals should appear to originate from the plume and not from their true source. It would, of course, be crucial to ensure that virtually no microwaves leak from the MASER in directions other than the intended direction; a longstanding challenge in the field. Novel, atomically thin metamaterials that block microwaves should mean that this goal is already attainable.

On a cautionary note, it is possible for the presence of these aerosol clouds to be detected even before they are utilized since they would create discernible echoes in other microwave signals such as those associated with cellular signals and FM radio. Operational prudence would call for plumes to be emitted on a time delay from a secondary location and not from the residence of the operative.

Here's some real history for those who are interested.
>The first documented systematic technique capable of determining integrals is the method of exhaustion of the ancient Greek astronomer Eudoxus (ca. 370 BC), which sought to find areas and volumes by breaking them up into an infinite number of divisions for which the area or volume was known.[1] This method was further developed and employed by Archimedes in the 3rd century BC and used to calculate the area of a circle, the surface area and volume of a sphere, area of an ellipse, the area under a parabola, the volume of a segment of a paraboloid of revolution, the volume of a segment of a hyperboloid of revolution, and the area of a spiral.[2]
(NOTE: 700 year time gap)
>A similar method was independently developed in China around the 3rd century AD by Liu Hui, who used it to find the area of the circle. This method was later used in the 5th century by Chinese father-and-son mathematicians Zu Chongzhi and Zu Geng to find the volume of a sphere.[3]
>In the Middle East, Hasan Ibn al-Haytham, Latinized as Alhazen (c.965 – c.1040 AD) derived a formula for the sum of fourth powers.[4] He used the results to carry out what would now be called an integration of this function, where the formulae for the sums of integral squares and fourth powers allowed him to calculate the volume of a paraboloid.[5]

>>15188192
RL-10s are cheap, they're just sold for a high profit margin. The RS-68 is "cheap" compared to the RS-25, but that's not really much of a statement. The TR-106 would have been pretty cheap if anyone had ever finished it, but it was an engine without a rocket. The RD-0120 was cheap, but all Soviet shit was cheap after the wall came down.

Hydrogen is a bitch+ to work with, but it's not so bad that it makes engines impossible to make economical. Working with hydrogen isn't like working with something crazy like fluorine. If an engine is expensive it's because of something other than the fuel choice.

>>15188067
Assuming nothing blows up. Inspection of the concrete and engines and surrounding locations. If all passes as green. Then submission for launch license. Then stacking, fuel load, and to orbit it goes.

And then a lot of praying that it clears the tower without blowing up, then clears 100m without blowing up. Then clears 500m without blowing up. Then clears 1km without blowing up. Then clears 5km without blowing up. Then 10km without blowing up. Then 20km without blowing up. Then 40km without blowing up. Then 80km without blowing up; and around where stage separation happens without blowing up. Then reentry and Falcon 9 profile style landing in the ocean without blowing it up. Then Starship going around the Earth without blowing up. Then reentry without blowing up. Then sky diving without blowing up. Then landing sequence without blowing up. Then landing into the ocean without blowing up.

Then, finally then, for booster and ship, praying that it actually blows up when it tips over and smashes into the ocean.

The inner ring (including central 3 engines) can gimbal, the outer cannot. Space between inner and outer is necessary for gimbaling, same as the space between inner and central 3 engines. Setup also is this way to maximally distribute upwards force against the thrust puck.

>>15180038
What filtered me was how pointless learning any of this bullshit was with no connection to its historical development or science.
> Calculus
For a simple example, the number e came from logarithm tables which is never mentioned. The number Napier chose as the base for his logarithm tables was (1 + 1/10^7)^(10^7), which happens to be a good approximation of e, and is also a natural choice for the base given what these tables were used for. Once that makes sense you can work out the area under a hyperbola 1/x fairly easily through clever partioning.
> linear algebra
I did not understand linear algebra until I saw 3blue1browns videos. I ended up working out the scalar triple product and running into Levi cevita symbols because of how much that series got me thinking.
> real analysis
This was the effort to put calculus on solid foundations after fourier series blew the field apart.

The way math is taught is an embarrassment. Terrence Tao said the best way to learn math was gaining an intuition, formalizing those intuitions, and then learning the subject again informally once your comfortable with it.

The process has been reversed. One receives a formal education and then is supposed to gain an intuition for these things they have no clue about, studied for their own sake when they were developed alongside physics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
concepts that that are not based on physical reality, or are based on unproven conjectures about physical reality, and paraded around as mathematical fact by people, especially people on /sci/. Yes they can be mathematical facts, but they are not neccessary to describe reality, and in fact, only lead to confusion. They also lead to petty semantic games where mathematicians define an ordinary word to mean something other than it does in real life. This leads to people "disproving" other people's claims by disproving it for the mathematically defined version of the word instead of the vernacular version, which is a fallacy. It also leads to people telling others that they don't know the "true" mathematical definitions of the words and that they should study more before voicing their opinions. And aswell leads to people conflating mathematical terminology with vernacular terminology that are completely different ideas, just because they are tangently related, and happen to use the same words (due mostly to mathematician's hubris in an attempt to declare they know the true meaning of the word, not even linguists have this level of certainty about the meaning of vernacular words even though they have more knowledge on the subject)
Examples of such concepts which have no basis in reality or are unproven but paraded as facts, or are seperate from their vernacular meaning are the following:
>number
seperate from its vernacular meaning
>continuity of space and analogous concepts (such as the continuity of numbers when applied to space)
unproven
>points in space with no width
unproven
>the cardnial 1 as the set of all singleton sets
seperate from the vernacular meaning
>sets in ZFC
people conflate these with groups of things in reality, when they aren't the same concept.
the most a mathematician can say to these critisims are "they are useful, therefore we use them". But that does not give you the right to parade them around as pillars of certain truth, because they are not.

It's easy
[math] p = \sqrt{3} q [/math]
[math] p^2 = 3 q^2 [/math] or that [math] p^2 = k^2 q^2 [/math] where [math] k^2 =3 [/math] for an integer [math] k [/math]. Therefore
[math] p = k q [/math] so that [math] k= \sqrt{3} [/math] is an integer. Therefore [math] \sqrt{3} [/math] is an integer. This is a contradiction since [math] 1<\sqrt{3}<2 [/math].

>>15184329
Suppose [math] p,q [/math] have no common factors, or are coprime. This is reasonable since any rational number can be written with a numerator and denominator that share no common factors.
[math] p^2 = 3 q^2 [/math]
So [math] 3|p^2 [/math]. By the fundamental theorem of arithmetic [math] 3|p [/math] so that [math] p = 3 k [/math] for an integer [math] k[/math]. Then [math] 9k^2 = 3q^2 [/math] so that [math] q^2 = 3k^2 [/math]. This likewise implies [math] 3|q [/math]. This is a contradiction since [math] p, q [/math] have no common factors.
